The Frozen North

OSINT Bellingcat Challenge of December 2025

The Frozen North

Spoiler alert: challenge solution ahead

This is my guide on how to solve an OSINT challenge, this time from Bellingcat. This solution is given step by step, as to reflect my thinking process.

Description of the challenge

The challenge description is shown in Figure 1. It describes a situation where a ship docked at a port. The challenge is to find the IMO-number of the ship using open source intelligence (OSINT) techniques.

My first approach was to use Google lens and see if any of the shapes matched on Google images. However, this didn't yield any good results.

Next, I decided I needed to use a more analytical approach. As per usual, I started off by listing everything we know by looking at the image. What can we see?

  • It is a satalite image
  • The environment looks cold
  • There seems to be a road running from north to south, and what looks like a road following the coastline
  • The large body of water which the ship is in is likely to be a sea
  • Small structures are visible. The structures don't seem to be houses
  • The ship is docked at a port (so not at a random point on the coastline)
  • Judging by the title of the challenge, the location is in the Northern Hemisphere
  • It is safe to assume the top of the image shows North, as is standard with satalite imagery

    • Initial approaches

    My first approach was to start up Marinetraffic. Using the map, you can see a list of ports on the map. I went trough each port on the sea in the Artic to check if they matched the location. This took a lot of time and it turned out to be a waste of time, as there is no match.

    In a act of desperation, I decided to use Google Earth and scour the coastline of Siberia, Alaska, Greenland and Canada and focus on coastal settlements. This took even more time, and although I liked doing this, it also was not helpful.

    By this time I spent a lot of time on this challenge already, by my estimate, an easy 16 hours. I knew that there had to be a smarter approach. I left the challenge for what it was for a few days, and next time I booted it up, I had an eureka moment.

    Overlooking the obvious

    I decided to check the image again. Normally, I do download the image to check the metadata and to open the image in my photo-editor, as this allows me to see more details and zoom in further. And what did i Notice? The filename of the picture contained useful information. There is a date and time visible: .../20220901_091318-C5etx_H-.png. The image was taken in 2022, at the first of September, at 09:13.

    The screenshot Bellingcat provided was taken from a website that has satalite information. We know that the timezone is UTC, as this is the standard for satalite imagery. Furthermore, we can just see a bit of shade in the image, which gives us a clue about the relative position of the sun.

    Having fun with Suncalc and timeszones

    At this point, I was very confident that I found the way to the solution to this challenge. Now I know where the sun was likely to be, I needed to play around on the map with timezones to get it just right.

    UTC is the same as GMT, or in other words, the time in Greenwich at the moment the satalite image was taken. If you fill in the date and time into Suncalc and place it on Greenwich, you can see the location of the sun.

    As you can see in Figure 3, the sun is too far east. That means we are looking at a place that is further east. We have to take timezones into account here. Shifting the location of the sun to the east, and also adjusting the timezone to match, we can match the location of the sun as shown in Suncalc to the location of the sun that we derived from the satalite image.

    From this moment on, we have a rough idea where the port should be. Following the line north of our placed location on Suncalc, we can see that it intersects with the artic coastline at different points.

    First, Google maps was used to scout settlements on the north-coast of syberia, but nothing matched. Did the same thing on Novya Zemla, and again, no match.

    Wikipedia helps us out

    One more option were the Franz Joseph islands, and I looked on Wikipedia if there were any settlements: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Franz_Josef_Land. Interestingly, the article does in fact mention the presence of a Russian military base, namely Nagurskoye.

    Google maps shows the location of Nagurskoye, and it is clear that this is the location the ship was at in September 2022.

    The roads are still distinguisable, and the little structures are also still there. Yes, they build a pier and the lake on the North is not clearly visible, but still, the location is a definite match!

    Finding the IMO number

    We now now the location, date and time of the ship. Next, we need to find what ship it was, find the IMO number, and confirm it is really matches the ship in the image.

    Global Fish Watch (GFW) stores all the necessary information for us to find out what ships were at that location at September 1, 2022. Using GFW, the date and location gave the following information: https://globalfishingwatch.org/map/index?longitude=48.08866794722606&latitude=80.72000786550042&zoom=9.162824836837329&start=2022-09-01T00%3A00%3A00.000Z&end=2022-09-02T00%3A00%3A00.000Z&dvIn[0][id]=loitering&dvIn[1][id]=presence&dvIn[1][cfg][vis]=true&dvIn[2][id]=vms&dvIn[2][cfg][vis]=false&dvIn[3][id]=ais&dvIn[3][cfg][vis]=false&bDV&tV=events

    Only one ship was present at that location: the Mekhanik Pyatlin.

    GFW shows that the IMO number of the ship is the following: 8904434.

    Looks like we found the number. But as an extra check we can also check Vesselfinder.org, and see if the shape and colours of the ship match what we can see on the satellite image.

    As you can see in Figure 9, the shape of the ship matches the shape of the ship in the satalite image. The colours also match. So we can be quite certain that the IMO number 8904434 is indeed the correct answer to this challenge.

    Conclusion

    This OSINT challenge was a real test of my skills. It also shows that changing ones approach to a more analytical one is key to solving complex problems. Being persistant and using the right tools helped a lot to solve this challenge, and from the moment I used Suncalc to finding the IMO-number of the ship only took me about 10 minutes.

    I hoped you enjoyed this challenge as much as I did, and maybe you even learned something new from it!
